Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2009 01:59PM Jill45 wrote: I am on Tamoxifen and Zometa and I am recovering from surgery in May for a bone met in my femur. I have gone thru periods of alot of muscle aches and stiffness and what I have found is that excersise helps out the most. Seems strange that when all you want to do is lie down and rest to force your body to excercise but for me it helps. I also know that the week after my Zometa IV that I am alot stiffer than usual. I also work FT and have more stiffness when I get up from sitting for any period of time.  I try to get in atleast 30 minutes each day of some type of excerise - usually either on the bike or eliptical. I have also started to work with a personal trainer who has given me some great stretching exercises that I can do daily to help loosen up the muscles. Jill
Posts.Title: Help with muscle aches Jan50 Analemma

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2016 03:54PM Jill45 wrote: 7.5 years since original Stage IV diagnosis with mets to bones and liver. Was on Tamoxifen for 6 months then switched to Femera which I have been on for last 7 years. Cancer has been stable since I have been on Femera and Tumor markers are all normal. Have not had any tests to confirm whether the cancer make up has changed since original diagnosis. Was also on Xygeva up until Jan 2016 when I fell on some ice and fractured my Femur they feel that the Xygeva could have been a reason that the bone fractured so easily. I stay very active and exercise on a regular basis.
Posts.Title: ER+ PR+ HER - longterm survival sharethehope Celebrate_Life

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2011 10:36AM Jill45 wrote: I have been on Femera for 2 years and what I have found is that exercise helps reduce the stiffness. I am fortunate in that I have only 1 bone met in my left femur and it has been surgically repaired.  I still have a good QOL am able to exercise on a regular basis, which helps reduce the stiffness. It seems odd to exercise when your body is achy and stiff but it seems to help.I will still get stiff if I sit around for any period of time - but after the 1st couple of steps it tends to go away.  I also take Glucosamine on a daily basis to help counter some of the joint pain and stiffness.
Posts.Title: Femara stiffness Leah_S ibcmets

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2012 08:42AM Jill45 wrote: Will be 3 years in May for me - have been on Femera for over 2 years and have seen regression of the liver mets. Currently stable and enjoying life!!

Posts.Content: Jill45 wrote: I was diagnosed in 5/09 with stage IV with mets to my femur and liver. The tumor is Estrogen Progesterone + and Her2-. At this time it appears as if 1 lymph node is impacted. I have undergone surgery to remove the tumor in my leg, and just completed radiation on the femur. We have received 2 different opinions on treatment options. Doctor 1 - Currently has me on Tamoxifen and if it holds the cancer in check or shrinks it he would not recommend chemo Doctor 2 - Feels we should do chemo 1st because of the mets to the liver - either Taxol or Abraxine with Avastin and then switch to hormone drugs Any experience with either option? Dx 5/19/2009, Stage IV, Grade 2, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2011 04:57PM Jill45 wrote: I also question this group - they call frequently asking for donations and will only speak to my husband. The caller messed up one time and told me who they were - I listened for a while then I told them that I had breast cancer and that we give to several cancer organizations already. I asked if they could send something in the mail for us to review because I wanted to understand what they used the money for - the caller got upset and said that they were just trying to save lives and hung up. Needless to say my husband now knows how they operate and we will never donate to this organization.
Posts.Title: This kind of thing drives me crazy. lynne248 pbandj

Posts.Content: May 21, 2013 08:03PM Jill45 wrote: I am on Letrozole and Xgeva with calcium 600 mg, vitamin d 2000 mg, multi purpose vitamin. I also take a GNC glucosamine packet to help minimize side effects of Letrozole and joint pain. Been on Xgeva for 2+ yrs - currently just get shot quarterly.
Posts.Title: Xgeva users - step up naturegirl2 Suesbooby2

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2012 10:54AM Jill45 wrote: I actually ended up getting 3 opinions - I was diagnosed Stage IV at the start and it was by a doctor about 2 hrs from home. His recommendation was to go with chemo to start and then transition to hormonals - he referred us back to a onc in our home town who said hormonals 1st and save the big guns for later when you need them. When we pushed the 1st doctor on why the difference - his response was it has alot to do with how you were trained. We then went to Mayo and they agreed with the hormonal route. 3 years laters still on hormonals - last 2.5 on Femera. Stable with a very good quality of life and very happy we got other opinions.
Posts.Title: Second opinion says to wait on chemo?? SonnyB raro

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2011 08:46PM Jill45 wrote: Sorry you had to join us. I was also diagnosed stage IV with bone and liver mets. I started on Tamoxifen and switched after 6 months to Femera. We swicthed because of some issues in the liver - not sure if it was progression or fatty liver from the Tamoxifen. Have been on Femera now for 2 years and liver mets continue to shrink and tumor markers are in normal range. Also take Xgeva for the bone mets and have not had any progression since the original met in my femur. I also have not had any chemo and quality of life has been very good on the hormonals. I do have some bone and joint pain but have found that exercise helps reduce that side effect. My oncologist has told me that when Femera fails we would just transition to another AI drug unless for some reason he felt that the cancer had changed and become more aggressive. I am hoping for a very long run on the AI's.
Posts.Title: Hormone therapy ? mylifelisa Chickadee

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2009 09:23PM Jill45 wrote: Geech - I had a femur met that was about 3cm and my doctors were concerned about the possibility of the leg breaking so they removed the growth and back filled with a cement compound and added a pin in the femur for stability. I also had 10 rad treatments after the surgery. I had the surgery in May, 2009 and I have always been very physically active. I started rehab witin 1 month of surgery and after 4 months I was back to golfing and playing tennis
Posts.Title: Hip, Femer,both ribs GEECH Honeybear

Posts.Content: May 2, 2010 08:33PM Jill45 wrote: Nicki - I had the pin/hardware inserted in my left femur. I had the surgery on Wed and was home on Saturday using a walker or crutches for the 1st few weeks then transitioned to a cain. By the 2 month mark I was walking without any aids just a slight limp. I see that you are in Chicago - I had my surgery at Froedert Hospital in Milwaukee they have a great orthopedic surgeon on staff that was awesome to work with. He actually is a cancer survivor himself so he was very understanding of the battle we face. I was off of work for about 2 weeks - and then my employer allowed me to work part time on STD from home for about 6 weeks until I felt good enough to come back into the office and work full time. Jill
Posts.Title: No bone mets surgery for me:( Lisa73 palaminoridesagain

Posts.Content: May 2, 2010 05:51PM Jill45 wrote: I was diagnosed stage IV last May and I got several opinions on the removal of the tumor and treatment. The one thing that was consistent from a treatment plan was to leave the tumor in until we could determine that the drugs were having the desired impact. I started with Tamoxifen and has some complications with Fatty liver and switched to Femera. Femera has done a good job of keeping me stable and shrinking the liver mets. Once I was stable the doctor recommended a lumpectomy and lymph node removal which I had in March along with a ooph. The surgery went well and I definitely feel better knowing that the primary source of my cancer is out of my body. Good Luck
Posts.Title: No removal of breast tumor mohonda mohonda

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2009 07:33PM Jill45 wrote: Hi Cathy, For me the orthopedic doctor was to concerned with the potential of me fracturing the femur and I actually had my femur stabilized surgically and the bone met removed. I then had 10 treatments of rads to the surgical area. This occurred at the end of May and I was walking without a cain in about 2 months. If I remember from some of your other posts that you like to travel and are pretty active. I am also very active and was back to my normal activities including travel, golf & tennis roughly 4-5 months after surgery. I do not have any history with rads only hopefully they work for you. If you have any specific questions about my procedure feel free to pm me. Jill
Posts.Title: Did rads help improve bone strength/mobility? Cathy-CA Jill45

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2012 08:38AM Jill45 wrote: I have been on Femera for almost 3 yrs - in that time period I have had all spots shrink and I am currently stable. The biggest side effect is the joint pain and bone stiffness - I take glucosamine daily to counter that and also makes sure I stay active. If you wake up in the am and are stiff - just keep moving and I have found that it eventually goes away. Not permanently but enough that it allows me to stay active and lead a normal life.

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2009 06:25PM Jill45 wrote: Sherri They should be able to tell how positive she is for ER/PR based on the biopsy results. If they do not have it in the patholgy report this is something you should still be able to get. The clinic that did my original biopsy only had that it was positive which meant that it was atleast 10% I just recently had another clinic run the test so I knew how postive I was, since it definitely helps in understanding how effective hormone therapy might be. If they decide to place your mom on Tamoxifen they can also run a cypd26 test to make sure her body is metabolizing the drug. I have been on Tamoxifen since May and my primary tumor has shrunk by 30% already. Jill
Posts.Title: hormone therapy in place of chemotherapy ForMyMother ForMyMother

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2010 07:14AM Jill45 wrote: I had 10 days of rads to my femur post surgery - I started about 1 month out from surgery. I did have some pain and stiffness but it is hard to say if that was from the rads or still from the surgery. I will still get stiffness in my leg/hip if I sit for a period of time but this is probably from the AI that I am on. The stiffness goes away after the 1st few steps. Jill

Posts.Content: May 8, 2010 07:49PM Jill45 wrote: I've been on Femara for 7 months and the stiffness in my fingers and hands continues to get a little worse over time. I can not really bend the thumb on my right hand without help. The stiffness is the worst in the am. My feet also get stiff at times - but once I get moving it gets better. I can tolerate the stiffness as long as the drug continues to work.

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2010 05:50PM Jill45 wrote: I have been lucky in that although I had bone mets in my femur after surgery I have no exercise limitations. I play tennis twice a week, and try to work out 2-3 other days doing cardio and weights. I have found that it definitely helps with the stiffness that I get from the AI's and my energy level as well. If your doctor is fine with exercise just start slow and work your way back.
